--- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:

> My experience is that testing on an emulator should be the first
> priority because it will catch a lot of bugs that will happen on *all* 
> devices.
> Once you have a comprehensive emulator test suite, you will probably see
> that your code works fine on 90% of the devices and that 10% of them
will
> require additional debugging (on-device this time, since these bugs 
> didn't show on the emulator).
> 
> Most of the bugs that I see in JavaME applications are simple
> programming errors, not device-specific errors, and they can therefore
be > exposed and tested in an emulator. But maybe your experience differs?

I must admit I don't have much experience testing applications in a ME
setting yet. I am, however, doing some testing of a java application which
is supposed to run on both J2SE 1.3 and above and J2ME CDC/Foundation. So
far, I have not tested this on J2ME platforms (or equivalent emulators). 

I agree totally that most most bugs are probably programming errors that
are relevant to all J2ME devices. I also agree that testing on an emulator
would be convenient and beneficial. But when a suitable emulator is not
available, testing on a small device, or using a J2ME vm on a desktop
machine as I mentioned earlier, is probably better than no testing at all.
That is why I asked if there are any knwon issues using JUnit and/or
TestNG on a J2ME CDC device.

-- 
John
